ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual Seminar twice a week on zoom. Small format, 8 students
This course was mainly reading, discussion, and writing.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned more about what it means to be a good tourist. I was also given feedback and insights on how to improve my writing as a whole. Another aspect that I learned how to do in this class was how to properly do a close read of a section of writing.
Writing skills were developed. Also expanded my world view.
I developed clear writing and analysis skills, through peer review and thorough support from the professor. I viewed 'Travel' in a new light and was able to do so in a structured way.
Lots of travel philosophy; how to formulate an argument using certain lenses; how to read travelogues
I developed the skill to intricately mix the various viewpoints about travel and compare them with each other, occasionally through a lens perspective.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the course was structured really well in the way that during every class we had something to discuss and it was really open which allowed lots of participation and for the class to generate our own ideas.

Professor De La Rocha was amazing! He made the course very engaging as he encouraged participation but in a very organic way. He always knew how to spark a discussion and understood cues for transitioning topics. The class was always lively and I believe the course would not be the same without him. I really enjoyed the class-wide discussions on books and readings, as I felt like they always had a purpose and were related to the syllabus. I believe that in the future, more breakout discussions could be used to have more peer-peer feedback.
Course was amazing, I have no complaints. For it being virtual, I was amazed how much I got out of this course.

One strength of this course was the various angles from which the concept travel was examined.

One part I thought could happen more was a bit more interweaving between different readings and topics. This interweaving was definitely present in our class discussion. However, I did crave for a bit more. Since we covered so many readings, we couldn't analyze each and every sentence of those readings. I don't think this badafter all, we did get to read about diverse viewpoints. However, a bit more time spent on each reading may be nice.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that having an open seminar like discussion every week on zoom worked really well. We were able to collaborate and discuss our own opinions of a reading or film.

I believe that the small class really benefitted from the virtual format. I enjoyed writing essays on our own time and meeting twice a week to discuss the material. Professor De La Rocha always made himself available after class to discuss paper topics and progress as well.
We had zoom discussions, which may sometimes be hard to be fully engaged, however Danny facilitated some of the best conversations I have had with my peers and instructors at Yale.

Because the class focused on verbal discussion, the course practices were not very influenced by the online format. The nature of the course did not require more complex course practices as verbal discussion was most dominant.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes
Yes, this was a very good course that can help solidify basic skills in writing. Also, if you are an avid traveler or tourist, this course can introduce you to new perspectives.

Absolutely! The course is full of entertaining gems that really allows one to reflect on the role of "travel" in our society. The small-class format really allows discussions to flourish and I enjoyed learning from my classmates. Professor De La Rocha was so concerned about the well-being of his students and left me no doubt he wanted us to succeed amidst the global pandemic. I had never taken a writing seminar before and this was definitely the highlight of an overall very difficult semester.

I highly recommend taking this course with Professor de la Rocha (or Danny as we all came to know him). He is very knowledgable in travel writing as a genre and he leverages these insights incredibly well in our discussions about readings. I also thought the reading selection was exquisite, especially for someone like myself who had not previously read anything travel-related; I also found myself becoming a better reader (weird as that might sound coming from a Yalie) and much more proficient in analyzing texts through a variety of different lenses and perspectives. If Danny is teaching the course, I cannot recommend it enough! You will find yourself fascinated by all the nuances you encounter in your readings and class discussions, and I think the course is the perfect introduction to both the genre and the skill of writing effective essays in college.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in travel and loves thought provoking discussion. (and wants to improve their writing skills tenfold).

As long as the student is interested in the topic of "travel," I definitely recommend this course. The readings were diverse, exploring the idea of travel from multiple perspectives and from different times. The readings supplemented each other, and the essay prompts challenged us to think about travel with varying depths and angles. This course was definitely my favorite this semester.
